channel.title: 5k on LIMINAL RUNNER
channel.description: Recent content in 5k on LIMINAL RUNNER

item.title: 5k Plan: (Final) Week 8
item.description:
Weekly Update #4

This was the last week of the 8 week 5k Plan I have been following. The good news, I got my 5k paced run done. The bad news, I am sick/hurt at the moment.

First, here is the weekly overview:

Monday was a tempo run, going through multiple paces, nothing new but good fun.

I did my “timed” 5k run on Thursday because I was not sure if I could get a run in on Friday or Saturday.
The Nike Run Club 5k Training plan gives a whole table of paces for people in different states of fitness/ability. Because it has been a while since I ran i started this plan on the slowest level of their pace table. That translates to

1k pace 5k pace 10k pace recovery pace
7:30 7:55 8:10 9:00

This would translate to a 12:00 mile pace, you can do the rest of the math yourselves. :)
Following this pace, this would set me up with a 39:30 5k time. I am aware that this is super slow. But I am just competing against myself and not against others. For me this is about finishing it and having fun doing it. Getting faster is something that will come with time.

For the run itself I did about an 800m warmup followed by a few minutes of dynamic stretches. In the last weeks I always felt sluggish on my long runs without having a proper warmup because i thought that at an easy recovery speed I don’t need one (the training plan also didn’t mention one, but does in interval/tempo/fartlek/hill workouts). With this warmup I was ready to go, no sluggish feeling!
Just for the hell of it I did it without looking at my watch to get a gps pace estimate.
Keep in mind the table above with the paces I was going for, here are the “personal records” I set this run:


The first km was the 6:37min/km time, up till the 3k mark, i continued running below 7:00 min/km. Around the 3k mark I had to slow down to a slow jog for a around 20 seconds to get my breathing under control. I finished running an 7:10 min/km average for the whole distance, which means I was 4min faster than the pace I was aiming for. On one side, I now know that I can run a 5k faster than the target pace I set for myself which sounds good, on the other side, I couldn’t pace myself at all. As I said, after 3k my breathing was all over the place. This is something I am not happy about. I guess if i kept the pace at around 7:15 min/km I could’ve run the whole 5k still struggling, but without slowing down or have my breathing go out of control.

Friday was an easy recovery run.

But that’s also when I started feeling a pain in my ribs. I had a slightly annoying feeling in my ribs since monday morning, when stretching after waking up. Which i thought was just me having slept in a weird position or something similar and I only felt it when I fully extended my arms which put a lot of pressure in my ribcage.
At the end of the friday run, I had pain on the right side my ribcage while taking deep breaths which later throughout the day also happened on any major movement like sitting down/getting up or lifting something heavy enough for the muscles near the area to engange. After a visit to my GP, I ended up with the diagnosis of it being an inflammation, possibly from some viral infection and a prescription for some pain killers.
Which led to me finding out that ibuprofen doesn’t seem to do a good job for me on this, because as someone who usually falls asleep while lying on my side, that was impossible. I missed a lot of sleep the last 2 days and I have been in pain. No running at the moment. I hope that this will be gone in a few days.

But this is my 5k training plan done and now I have little bit of time to look for what to do next. I mentioned it in a previous post already, I am looking for a longer distance training plan, especially for a half marathon, which seems to be still managable timewise. I have looked at a few, nothing set in stone yet, might continue with the Nike HM plan, or maybe I might give the Garmin Coach Half Marathon feature which you have access to if you have a garmin watch a try, at least for a week or two to see what it will look like, since it seems to adapt itself to your performance. But I am meanwhile also looking at other plans, tons of them out there on the net.

That’s it for this week, thanks for reading. Hope to see you again!.

item.title: 5k Plan: Week 7
item.description:
Weekly Update #3

Another week gone by. Some unexpected things came up and I only got to do 3 runs:

Monday was a hill interval workout at different speeds, a first for me. I was on a road that according to google maps should have around 6-7% inclination through a vineyard. I didn’t mind going uphill at all, but the fact that I had to go back down just to get up again between every interval was slightly annoying. I don’t like walking or running downhill in general.
Wednesday were flat intervals. I am learning that I really do enjoy intervals.
Friday was long run day with a 5k. Had the same problem as last week, that the first 1 or 2 km it just felt sluggish and I couldn’t get into a comfortable pace. Don’t know what the problem is there, they were both run at an easy pace but it just didn’t feel good at the start. Maybe I need to do some warmup or something.

Coming week is the last of this 5k training plan and I am thinking about what to do after I am done with this plan. I know that I am not fast at all, but haven’t run 5k at an not easy pace, so I don’t really know what my time could be. So going for a faster 5k time could be something to work on. But I feel more drawn to increasing the distance. The 5k training plan I am using now is from Nike and offers Audio Guided Runs for every run, which I liked a lot. I’ve seen that they also offer this kind of plan for 10k, half marathon and marathon. I am thinking about aiming for that half marathon distance. Going from 5k to 21.1k is a lot not just the distance but also the time commitment. Long run days will take hours of my time, which is something I’ll have to consider. I’ll also have to think about hydration and/or nutrition. I never carried anything with me so far, because I knew I would be back home within an hour at the longest. I’ll also look into half marathon training plans that are available on the internet to see how they differ from the Nike one.

That is all, till next week.

item.title: 5k Plan: Week 6
item.description:
Weekly Update #2

This was week 25 of 2020 and week 6 of the 5k Training Plan I am following.
Here are the stats from my watch, since it already flipped over to monday, the 7 day overview left out last monday, the 15th:

Only had time to do 4 runs this week.
The missing Monday was an interval workout, Wednesday was a tempo run and the long run, which I did on Friday this week was for 6.5km / 4 Miles ( which ended up being 6.95km). Since these long runs are supposed to be run at an easy pace, the length itself wasn’t a problem at all. But the first 1-2km I had real problems finding that easy pace, but at around 2k I settled into a comfortable pace which i held (with small variations) to the end without much of a problem. Pretty happe with this weeks progress.

Next weeks workouts include an interval run on a hill. The hills here go all over the place with inclination, so I am just going pick one and will keep going up that one. That workout will probably be hard on me, since the runs I always do are pretty much flat with only a small net elevation change.

See you next post.

item.title: 5k Plan: Week 5
item.description:
Weekly Update #1

It is week 24 of 2020 and today I finished week 5 of the Nike 5k Training Plan I am following.

Here are the stats from my Garmin watch:

As you can see I managed to go on 5 runs, as per the training plan those were 2 tempo/interval runs, 2 recovery runs and 1 long run. The interval run on Tuesday was slightly longer than the actual long run, but thats to be expected on these “short” distances I guess.
I am pretty happy with how this week went down, weather was around 15-22°C for most of the week, just about right for me, but windy and rainy on 2 of the days. The only thing that felt off was the pacing, I went all over the place. Not sure if I somehow get influenced by the music I am listening to while the Audio Guides are silent or if I just suck at sticking to a pace in general, but that’s definitely something to work on, other than me being slow.

Next week the planend long run is for 6.5km or 4 Miles which is around the distance I ran before I stopped running over a year ago.
The tempo/interval runs in this training plan all have a 5 min warmup followed by optional stretching before the speed part which I’ve used to do some quick stretches which I remember from soccer practice almost 2 decades ago. I should look into what things to do for warmup, including for long and recovery runs.

This is all so far. Thank for reading this post. See you next Sunday (or maybe earlier).
